commit.message:
perf: add database indexes to optimize get_rows function (#13537)

## Summary
- Added two new composite indexes to the `cells` table to optimize
`get_rows` function performance
- Implemented DESC ordering on `updated_at` columns for efficient
reverse chronological queries
- Created manual migration after encountering autogenerate issues with
partial indexes

## Changes
### New Indexes
1. **`ix_cells_sheet_tab_versioned_col_hash_updated`**
- Columns: `sheet_id`, `tab_id`, `versioned_column_id`, `cell_hash`,
`updated_at DESC`
- Purpose: Efficient filtering by sheet/tab/column with fast access to
recent updates

2. **`ix_cells_max_updated_at_per_sheet_tab`**
- Columns: `sheet_id`, `tab_id`, `updated_at DESC`,
`versioned_column_id`
- Purpose: Fast MAX(updated_at) queries and ORDER BY updated_at DESC
operations

### Performance Impact
- The DESC ordering eliminates the need for PostgreSQL to read indexes
backwards
- Significantly improves queries that need to find recent updates
- Optimizes common patterns in the get_rows function

## Code References - Queries That Benefit From These Indexes

### Call Chain
1. **Entry Point**:
[`sheets/routes/sheets.py:2038`](https://github.com/hebbia/mono/blob/29deb3d1e0ab4c68f6854ba99dbc77cb01342087/sheets/routes/sheets.py#L2038)
- `get_relevant_rows()` called from route handler
2. **Main Function**:
[`sheets/data_layer/cells.py:913-1023`](https://github.com/hebbia/mono/blob/29deb3d1e0ab4c68f6854ba99dbc77cb01342087/sheets/data_layer/cells.py#L913-L1023)
- `get_relevant_rows()` orchestration
3. **Cached Implementation**:
[`sheets/data_layer/cells.py:1028`](https://github.com/hebbia/mono/blob/29deb3d1e0ab4c68f6854ba99dbc77cb01342087/sheets/data_layer/cells.py#L1028)
- `_get_relevant_rows_cached()`

### Critical Queries Using The New Indexes

#### 1. MAX(updated_at) Query - Uses
`ix_cells_max_updated_at_per_sheet_tab`

[`sheets/data_layer/cells.py:1834-1846`](https://github.com/hebbia/mono/blob/29deb3d1e0ab4c68f6854ba99dbc77cb01342087/sheets/data_layer/cells.py#L1834-L1846)
```python
async def _latest_cells_updated_at(
    sheet_id: str,
    tab_id: str,
    column_ids: list[str],
) -> Optional[datetime]:
    async with async_or_sync_session() as session:
        query = sa.select(func.max(Cell.updated_at)).where(
            Cell.sheet_id == sheet_id,
            Cell.tab_id == tab_id,
            Cell.versioned_column_id.in_(column_ids),
        )
```
This query runs on EVERY call to `get_relevant_rows()` to determine
cache invalidation.

#### 2. Latest Cells Query - Uses
`ix_cells_sheet_tab_versioned_col_hash_updated`

[`sheets/data_layer/cells.py:1810-1831`](https://github.com/hebbia/mono/blob/29deb3d1e0ab4c68f6854ba99dbc77cb01342087/sheets/data_layer/cells.py#L1810-L1831)
```python
def _latest_cells_query(
    sheet_id: str,
    active_tab_id: str,
    column_ids: list[str],
    cell_id: Optional[str] = None,
) -> Select:
    query = (
        sa.select(Cell)
        .distinct(Cell.cell_hash)
        .where(
            Cell.sheet_id == sheet_id,
            Cell.tab_id == active_tab_id,
            Cell.versioned_column_id.in_(column_ids),
        )
        .order_by(Cell.cell_hash, sa.desc(Cell.updated_at))
    )
```
This query pattern is used throughout the codebase for fetching the most
recent version of cells.

#### 3. Earliest Loading Cell Query - Benefits from
`ix_cells_max_updated_at_per_sheet_tab`

[`sheets/data_layer/cells.py:1797-1807`](https://github.com/hebbia/mono/blob/29deb3d1e0ab4c68f6854ba99dbc77cb01342087/sheets/data_layer/cells.py#L1797-L1807)
```python
async def get_sheet_earliest_loading_cell_created_at(
    sheet_id: str, version_column_ids: list[str]
) -> Optional[datetime]:
    async with async_or_sync_session() as s:
        stmt = sa.select(func.min(Cell.updated_at)).where(
            Cell.sheet_id == sheet_id,
            Cell.versioned_column_id.in_(version_column_ids),
            sa.cast(Cell.content["loading"].astext, sa.Boolean).is_(True),
        )
```

## Technical Notes
- Manual migration was required due to Alembic 1.8.1 issues with
reflecting partial indexes
- Updated Cell model to maintain consistency with database schema
- Both migration and model use `sa.text("updated_at DESC")` for
functional index expressions
- The indexes are designed to support the DISTINCT ON pattern used in
the queries

## Test Plan
- [ ] Verify migration runs successfully in staging
- [ ] Test get_rows function performance improvement
- [ ] Confirm no regression in existing queries
- [ ] Monitor index usage statistics post-deployment
- [ ] Validate cache invalidation continues to work correctly

🤖 Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

---------

Co-authored-by: Sisu Xi <xisisu@gmail.com>
Co-authored-by: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

commit.message: Set explicit 5-second database connection timeout (#13608) ## Summary - Set explicit 5-second database connection timeout to prevent long-hanging requests - Previously defaulted to AsyncPG's 60 seconds, causing requests to hang when connections couldn't be established ## Problem As identified in the investigation, database connections were using AsyncPG's default 60-second timeout when `connect_timeout_secs` was not specified (defaulted to `None`). When connection issues occurred, requests would hang for a full minute before failing, creating a poor user experience and making debugging difficult. happens often in prod, 1 minute asyncpg default 60 seconds timeout: https://github.com/MagicStack/asyncpg/blob/master/asyncpg/connection.py#L2088 why 5 seonds? most p99s are ~3 seconds. --------- Co-authored-by: Sisu Xi Co-authored-by: Claude Co-authored-by: graphite-app[bot] <96075541+graphite-app[bot]@users.noreply.github.com>

repository.description: Python services monorepo
repository.name: mono

commit.message:
feat: add logging to verify N+1 query protection in get_rows_utils (#13619)

## Summary
- Added logging to verify that N+1 query protection is working correctly
in `get_rows_utils.py`
- Tracks timing and counters to confirm the
`ctx.missing_version_columns_queued` flag prevents repeated database
queries
- Helps understand why the "Enabling tool for missing version columns"
log never appears in production

## Context
Investigation revealed that the log message "Enabling tool for missing
version columns" never appears in Datadog over 30 days. This PR adds
logging to verify that the N+1 protection mechanism (via the
`ctx.missing_version_columns_queued` flag) is working as intended.

## Changes
- **Timing metrics**: Added `row_processing_time` to measure the entire
row processing loop
- **Protection verification counters**: 
- `missing_columns_triggered`: Count of times missing columns block is
entered (should be 0 or 1, never N)
- `enqueue_triggered`: Whether matrix execution was enqueued (limited to
once by the flag)
- `ctx_missing_columns_already_queued`: Initial queue state to
understand why path may not trigger

## What This Verifies
The code appears to have an N+1 pattern (checking conditions inside an
N-row loop), but is protected by a flag that ensures the expensive
operation only happens once. These metrics verify:
- The protection is working (missing_columns_triggered should never be >
1)
- Why the code path isn't triggering (context not provided, flag already
set, or no missing columns)
- The actual performance impact via row_processing_time

## Test plan
- [ ] Deploy to staging and monitor new logging metrics in Datadog
- [ ] Verify `missing_columns_triggered` is always 0 or 1 (never > 1)
- [ ] Analyze why the missing columns path isn't triggered
- [ ] Review performance impact via `row_processing_time` metric
- [ ] Confirm N+1 protection is functioning as designed

🤖 Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

---------

Co-authored-by: Sisu Xi <xisisu@gmail.com>
Co-authored-by: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

commit.message:
Apply Hebbia writing guidelines to improve documentation clarity (#2)

- Remove buzzwords: "comprehensive", "battle-tested", "seamless"
- Add customer focus: Clear "so what" benefits for each tool
- Simplify language: Plain explanations instead of technical jargon
- Use action-oriented structure: Subject-verb-object with clear doers
- Eliminate clutter: Remove unnecessary words and phrases
- Document writing standards compliance in CLAUDE.md

Key improvements:
- README.md: Focus on practical benefits and user value
- CLAUDE.md: Add writing guidelines compliance section with learnings
- Both files: Clearer, more concise, customer-focused language

- Structured 6-step review process (Summary, Scores, Logical Errors, Grammar, Rewrites, Names)

by providing a consistent framework for reviewing and improving technical documents.

commit.message:
Add comprehensive technical writing guide for creating documentation (#18)

Created write_technical_docs.md with complete framework for producing high-quality
technical documentation including:

Features:
- Document strategy and understanding framework
- Comprehensive writing principles and style guide
- Audience-specific adaptation guidelines
- Complete templates for all document types:
  * Design Documents with full structure
  * Architecture Reviews with assessment framework
  * Technical Proposals (RFC format)
  * Post-Mortem documents with timeline tracking
- Quality assurance checklist and review process
- Common pitfalls with examples (wrong vs right)
- Writing tools and resources recommendations
- Document lifecycle management guidelines
- Quick reference for document lengths and timelines

This guide complements review_documents.md by focusing on the creation process
rather than review, providing engineers with everything needed to write
excellent technical documentation.

commit.message:
Add comprehensive PRD generation guide (#20)

Created work_prd.md with complete framework for generating Product Requirements
Documents from feature requests, including:

Features:
- 4-step process: Repository Analysis, Strategic Questions, PRD Generation, Organization
- Comprehensive PRD template with 12 major sections:
  * Executive Summary with problem/solution/impact
  * Goals & Success Metrics with measurable KPIs
  * User Stories in structured format
  * Functional Requirements (MVP/Post-MVP/Future)
  * Technical Requirements with architecture details
  * UX Requirements with flows and error handling
  * Clear Non-Goals to prevent scope creep
  * Acceptance Criteria and testing requirements
  * Dependencies & Risk analysis
  * Implementation Plan with phases
  * Open Questions tracking
  * Complete appendices and approval workflow

- Quality checklist covering content, clarity, stakeholder alignment, and implementation readiness
- Common pitfalls with wrong vs right examples
- Templates library for different PRD types (bug fix, minor enhancement, major feature)
- Best practices for writing clear, implementable requirements

This guide ensures product requirements are comprehensive enough for junior developers
to understand and implement features successfully, while maintaining alignment with
business goals and technical constraints.

Add Slack Explorer tool for workspace data analysis (#14)

- Created slack_explorer.py with comprehensive Slack API integration
- Supports 8 commands: channels, history, activity, search, reactions, users, dms, me
- Handles OAuth scope limitations gracefully with helpful error messages
- Added detailed documentation in explore_slack.md with examples and use cases
- Updated README.md to include Slack Explorer in tools list
- Updated config.py.template with Slack OAuth token placeholder and scope requirements
- Supports both bot tokens (xoxb-) and user tokens (xoxp-) with appropriate scope handling
- Includes Sisu Xi's user ID (U099T22QHS9) in documentation for quick reference

Features:
- List and analyze channels
- Get channel message history
- Track user activity patterns
- Search messages (with search:read scope)
- View message reactions
- List workspace users (with users:read scope)
- Access direct messages
- Get authenticated user information

repository.description: sharing a list of custom created tools & prompts & configs
repository.name: sisu-tools

commit.message:
Add date range support to exploration tools (#24)

- Add --from and --to parameters to Drive, Gmail, and Slack explorers
- Maintain backward compatibility with existing --days parameter
- Support flexible date ranges for activity queries
- Update documentation with examples and date format guidance
- Test all tools to ensure proper date filtering functionality

Drive Explorer:
- Updated list_recent_files, get_activities, get_collaboration_stats, export_activity_json
- Uses YYYY-MM-DD format for dates

Gmail Explorer:
- Updated get_inbox, get_sent, get_important, search_messages, analyze_email_stats, get_attachments
- Uses YYYY/MM/DD format for dates

Slack Explorer:
- Updated get_channel_history, get_user_activity, search_messages
- Uses YYYY-MM-DD format for dates

🤖 Generated with Claude Code

Co-authored-by: Sisu Xi <xisisu@gmail.com>
Co-authored-by: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>
